thread.title: Keith Ellison calls for impeachment investigations of Donald Trump | The Independent
thread.title_full: Keith Ellison calls for impeachment investigations of Donald Trump | The Independent

author: Justin Carissimo
title: Keith Ellison calls for impeachment investigations of Donald Trump | The Independent

locations.name: south lawn of the white house

text:
Representative Keith Ellison of Minnesota, one of the top candidates to lead the Democratic Party, has called for impeachment investigations of President Donald Trump’s conduct in office. 

"I think that Donald Trump has already done a number of things which legitimately raise the question of impeachment," he said on Wednesday night at CNN hosted debate in Atlanta. 
He went on to accuse President Trump of violating the Constitution's Emoluments Clause, which prohibits the President from receiving payments from foreign governments. Mr Trump has frequently drawn the ire of critics after hosting foreign diplomats at his ownership of his Washington DC. A Constitutional violation the President has promised to avoid by donating his earnings to the Treasury. 
Rep. Keith Ellison: Trump has already done a number of things that "raise the question of impeachment" #DNCDebate https://t.co/VoQY6vj5x9 
— CNN Politics (@CNNPolitics) February 23, 2017 Mr Ellison said that discussions about impeaching Mr Trump help protect the integrity of the presidency. "We need to begin investigations not to go after Donald Trump but protect the presidency of the United States to make sure nobody can monetize the presidency and make profit off it for his own game,” he added.

Large crowds attended the anti-Trump rally a day after U.S. President Donald Trump was sworn in as the 45th U.S. president.

2/18 Protesters hold up signage near the Washington Monument during the Women's March on Washington January 21, 2017 in Washington, DC. Large crowds are attending the anti-Trump rally a day after U.S. President Donald Trump was sworn in as the 45th U.S. president.
Drew Angerer/Getty
3/18 Protesters gather during the Women's March on Washington January 21, 2017 in Washington, DC. The march is expected to draw thousands from across the country to protest newly inaugurated President Donald Trump.
Aaron P. Bernstein/Getty
4/18 Protesters arrive at the Capital South Metro station for the Women's March on Washington on January 21, 2017 in Washington, DC. Following the inauguration of Donald Trump as the 45th president of the United States, the Women's March has spread to be a global march calling on all concerned citizens to stand up for equality, diversity and inclusion and for women's rights to be recognised around the world as human rights. 
Jessica Kourkounis/Getty
5/18 Protesters arrive on the platform at the Capital South Metro station for the Women's March on Washington on January 21, 2017 in Washington, DC. Following the inauguration of Donald Trump as the 45th president of the United States, the Women's March has spread to be a global march calling on all concerned citizens to stand up for equality, diversity and inclusion and for women's rights to be recognised around the world as human rights. 
Jessica Kourkounis/Getty
6/18 Demonstrators protest during the Women's March along Pennsylvania Avenue January 21, 2017 in Washington, DC.  Hundreds of thousands of protesters spearheaded by women's rights groups demonstrated across the US to send a defiant message to US President Donald Trump. 
Joshua Lott/AFP/Getty Images
7/18 WASHINGTON, DC - JANUARY 21: Protesters attend the Women's March on Washington on January 21, 2017 in Washington, DC. Following the inauguration of Donald Trump as the 45th president of the United States, the Women's March has spread to be a global march calling on all concerned citizens to stand up for equality, diversity and inclusion and for women's rights to be recognised around the world as human rights.

Democrats will vote in Atlanta on Saturday for their next chair from a pool of eight candidates. 
Mr Ellison is considered the front-runner with a slight ever over former Labor Secretary Tom Perez. In a recent survey from The Hill , 240 of the 447 voting DNC members declared which candidate they plan on supporting. Mr Ellison lead with 105 supporters over Mr Perez’s 57. The remaining candidates have less than a dozen supporters each and more than 50 voters said they were undecided.
